Award.AwardTitle: Building Understanding and Measurement of Secondary Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching (MKT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Research Council in 2013 released the report Monitoring Progress toward Successful K-12 STEM Education: A Nation Advancing?, which outlined 14 Indicators as well as the needed research and development to create a system to monitor the quality of STEM education in the nation. This project is funded in response to a Dear Colleague Letter request for research in the Promoting Innovation in Measurement and Evaluation program focused on developing research and tools to advance the nation's capability to measure these indicators. The researchers in this project will address Indicator 6: Teachers' science and mathematics content knowledge for teaching. This research builds on a successful program that is developing valid measures of teachers' Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching (MKT), which indicates that the mathematical knowledge teachers need to be successful with students is different than conventional mathematical knowledge. The research will test two hypotheses as follows: 1). the assessment design theory for elementary MKT assessment items extends to secondary MKT item design; and 2). Strong conventional mathematical knowledge, with a focus on knowledge of advanced mathematics, is more integral to secondary MKT than to elementary MKT. The project will include a convening of experts to identify the implications of the findings for future research and development around Indicator 6 in mathematics.

The project will use items for secondary teacher MKT that have been developed in prior NSF-funded research. The researchers will conduct cognitive interviews to determine the extent to which the teachers correctly respond to the items and the extent to which their rationale for their response is in alignment with the reasoning around specialized knowledge of mathematics for teaching or with conventional mathematical reasoning. The findings of the study will be the focus of an expert forum in which the findings from the study will structure the development of recommendations for the research and development agenda needed to develop valid and reliable indicators of secondary teachers' understanding of mathematical knowledge for teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There has been great interest in a new class of teacher knowledge tests designed to measure types of mathematical knowledge used especially in teaching practice, generally referred to as mathematical knowledge for teaching, or MKT. These assessments situate the test taker in teaching practice and ask them to use mathematical knowledge to, for example, evaluate an unconventional student solution strategy or select an example to counter a particular misconception. These items engage test takers in mathematical practices distinctive to the work that teachers do.

The funded study addresses indicator six of the National Research Council report, Monitoring Progress Toward Successful K-12 Education: A Nation Advancing?, the need for indicators of “teachers’ science and mathematics content knowledge for teaching. It responds to the fact that, despite substantial assessment development work, the field still lacks valid and reliable assessments of MKT for secondary-level teachers comparable to those previously developed for elementary- and middle-school level teachers. This study examined the nature of secondary level MKT, established preliminary validity evidence for potential assessment items, and culminated in an expert forum intended to generate discussion and consensus around the conceptualization and assessment of MKT at the secondary level.

Our key findings with respect to the validity of secondary-level MKT assessment items was that such items, written following a practice-based theory of item design originally developed in elementary contexts, can function as designed in capturing hypothesized knowledge. This contributes to a growing body of validity evidence around measurements of MKT and suggests that following this assessment design model is a potentially productive way to develop such assessments. We achieved two key findings with respect to the nature of the MKT measured by these assessment items. First, our evidence indicates that the mathematics measured by those items differs from conventional mathematical knowledge, further solidifying the claim that the MKT measured by this set of items includes, but is non-overlapping, with the mathematics secondary teachers might learn in conventional mathematics courses. Second, we collected evidence that none of the major theoretical frameworks available in the field mapped constructs of the framework onto the knowledge measured by discrete items, suggesting that these items measure connected sub-domains of MKT rather than compartmentalized ones. This finding suggests that traditional factor analysis techniques may not be the most effective approach to addressing elemental validity (Schilling & Hill, 2007) for assessment items written following a practice-based item design.

The study has resulted in the creation of a google drive that provides open access to the MKT items used in the study and other documentation, and we welcome interested parties to contact us to be added to the group. A report from the expert forum was published as part of the AMS blog post series (Lai & Howell, 2016) and can be found at: https://blogs.ams.org/matheducation/2016/10/03/conventional-courses-are-not-enough-for-future-high-school-teachers/
